title: Building sandcastles on UK beaches voted best childhood memory
text:
61 shares 79

Building sandcastles on Britain’s beaches has been voted as the country’s favourite childhood holiday memory, beating foreign holidays, day trips and flying to their destination.
Over 58 per cent of men and women surveyed revealed that their holidays on UK shores were their most memorable childhood holidays.
Of the 1,000 people polled, 42 per cent said that building sandcastles on UK beaches - from St Ives to Blackpool - was their favourite holiday memory.
New research has found that building sandcastles on UK beaches is the country's most-loved childhood holiday memory
Other surprising findings in the poll by Bar-Be-Quick included 63 per cent revealing that they preferred camping and caravanning to hotel stays and 78 per cent preferring family barbecues over expensive meals out.

Share this article Share 61 shares A whopping 75 per cent remembered playing in the swimming pool with friends more fondly than holiday day trips, while 61 per cent revealed that they preferred driving to their holiday destination over flying.
Such statistics shouldn't come as a complete shock, however, given that more people than ever are now holidaying in the UK, according to Visit England.
In fact, 58% of those surveyed said that holidays to UK beaches was their favourite childhood vacation, over heading abroad. Pictured: Blackpool
Between 2008 and 2013, the country's national tourist board has found that the number of English 'staycations' had jumped by 12 per cent.
In fact, 62 per cent of 1,000 people surveyed by Bar-Be-Quick said they'd chosen to holiday with their kids in the UK this summer, with Newquay and Bournemouth topping the poll of favourite destinations.
The reasons given for families holidaying in the UK included less stress (48 per cent), cost (37 per cent) and form of travel (15 per cent) being the deciding factors.
Today, 62% of those polled revealed that they'd chosen to holiday with their kids in the UK. Pictured: St Ives
Caroline Morris, Head of Sales at Bar-Be-Quick: 'People often assume that expensive trips abroad will be more memorable than breaks in this country.
'However, this goes to show that kids enjoy any holiday that involves a bit of adventure, and it doesn't matter where in the world they are.'
Despite the fact that the UK's summer weather can be unpredictable, the lure of home comforts and the opportunity to avoid flying seems to be more appealing to families than lugging all their necessities overseas to more tropical climates.
